channel.title: Instrument layering techniques
channel.description:
Does anyone have any tips or strategies for layering instruments?
For example, @Southborne wrote in another thread: "I don’t master in a different DAW. It’s mostly a bit of volume adjustment here and there. There are a few other tricks but volume is the main one."
I'd like to know if there's any good techniques around volume or layering, especially when you've got multiple layers. The best producers seem to get amazing rich sounds.
Does duplicating an instrument and playing both together really help? Does panning one copy left and the other right make any difference? That kind of stuff. Any thoughts?

item.title: Instrument layering techniques
item.dc:creator: DC_Band
item.description:
Is there value in panning a mix? Absolutely

It is surprising how much clarity can be achieved simply by assigning different elements their own “space” in the pan wheel. If you think your songs sound too muddy or cluttered, try this. I have also had excellent results duplicating individual elements and placing them opposite each other on the L/R spectrum.

see this article: http://thechurchcollective.com/tutorial/personal-mixing-part-two-panning

item.title: Instrument layering techniques
item.dc:creator: Southborne
item.description:
Use low pass and high pass to filter unnecessary parts of a sound, eg. filtering the bass out of a piano to allow a fat bass line to really shine. Conversely- take the top end out of a low sound to allow room for a high pitch sound to come through. This is a basic mixing technique but it really adds a lot by freeing up “audio realestate”- there’s only so much audio you can jam in.

item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
If your aim is to create one cohesive sound from two instruments you should be filtering them to remove overlapping frequencies.

Using a bassline as an example (which should be sitting centre in your mix):

______________________   _______________________

item.title: Instrument layering techniques
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
You can learn layering easily by going absolutely nuts with it. Get a nice pattern and copy the instrument as many times as you want. Then just play around with volume, filters, automation, octaves, switching sounds. There is no technique other than listening for what sounds good and tweaking the layers until they gel
